The 'C2 keywords' and 'weak cryptographic algorithm' findings appear to be erroneous pattern matches with no actual security implications. This is a legitimate educational resource for scikit-learn.

content.value_statement: Build powerful machine learning models without getting lost in complex documentation. Get instant access to proven algorithms, preprocessing techniques, and best practices for classification, regression, and clustering tasks.
actual_capabilities: Generate complete ML pipelines with preprocessing and model training
Compare multiple algorithms with cross-validation and hyperparameter tuning
Implement proper train/test splits and prevent data leakage
Select appropriate metrics for classification and regression tasks

limitations: Focuses on classical ML algorithms, not deep learning
Does not include automated feature engineering
Limited to tabular and text data (no image/video processing)

prompt_templates.title: Quick Classification
prompt_templates.scenario: I have customer data with churn labels
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a classification pipeline to predict customer churn using Random Forest. Include data splitting, preprocessing with StandardScaler, and evaluate with precision, recall, and F1-score.

prompt_templates.title: Model Comparison
prompt_templates.scenario: Need to find the best algorithm for my dataset
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and SVM for classification using 5-fold cross-validation. Use GridSearchCV for hyperparameter tuning and report the best model with optimal parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Clustering Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform clustering analysis on customer data using K-Means, DBSCAN, and Agglomerative clustering. Find optimal number of clusters and visualize results with PCA.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced Pipeline
prompt_templates.scenario: Mixed data types with missing values
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a pipeline for mixed numeric/categorical data with missing values. Use ColumnTransformer with different preprocessing, apply SMOTE for imbalanced data, and ensemble methods for final model.

output_examples.input: Create a classification model to predict loan defaults
output: Split data with stratification to maintain class balance
Built preprocessing pipeline with StandardScaler for numeric features
Trained Random Forest with 100 trees achieving 0.89 F1-score
Feature importance shows credit score and income as top predictors
Cross-validation confirms stable performance across folds

best_practices: Always use pipelines to prevent data leakage between preprocessing and modeling steps
Set random_state for reproducible results across different runs and algorithms
Use stratified splitting for classification to maintain class distribution in train/test sets
anti_patterns: Never fit preprocessing on entire dataset before splitting - causes data leakage
Avoid using accuracy for imbalanced datasets - use precision, recall, or F1 instead
Don't skip cross-validation when comparing models - single train/test split can be misleading

faq.question: Which algorithms require feature scaling?
faq.answer: SVM, KNN, Neural Networks, PCA, and linear models with regularization require scaling. Tree-based models don't need scaling.

faq.question: How do I handle categorical variables?
faq.answer: Use OneHotEncoder for nominal categories without order, OrdinalEncoder for ordered categories, and target encoding for high-cardinality features.

faq.question: What's the difference between GridSearchCV and RandomizedSearchCV?
faq.answer: GridSearchCV tries all parameter combinations exhaustively. RandomizedSearchCV samples random combinations, more efficient for large search spaces.

faq.question: How many clusters should I use for clustering?
faq.answer: Use the elbow method (plot inertia vs. number of clusters and look for the 'elbow'), silhouette score (higher is better, max at optimal k), or gap statistic (compares within-cluster dispersion to expected under null reference distribution). K-Means, MiniBatchKMeans, and AgglomerativeClustering require specifying k upfront, while DBSCAN and HDBSCAN determine clusters automatically based on density.
